metadata.titleEn: Late Cretaceous Cenozoic exhumation in Yanji area: low temperature thermochronology data set
metadata.description: This data is the fission track data, (U-Th - [SM]) / he apatite age, (U-Th) / he zircon age of granite. The samples are mainly collected from Phanerozoic granites in Tianfozhi mountain, southwest Yanji, Jilin Province, most of which are Jurassic granites, and a small number of Permian, Triassic and early Cretaceous granites. Apatite fission track ages are obtained by external detectors;（ U-Th - [SM]) / he apatite age and (U – th) / he zircon age were obtained by degassing apatite and zircon with 820 nm optical coupled  fiber-optically coupled diode laser and analyzed by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) ; The cooling history and exhumation history from Late Cretaceous to Cenozoic in Yanji area can be limited by the obtained data.
metadata.instructions:
File name: fission track ages are stored in the form of Excel table. The file names are "fission track data of the Yanji area. Xlsx", (U-Th - [SM]) he apatic ages "and" (U-Th) he Zircon Ages ", representing“Sampling points”, " fission track data "," U-Th - [SM]) / he apatite age "and" (U – th) / he zircon age ", respectively.
Data reading mode: the data can be directly opened by using the excel table

literatureList.titleEn: Study on Late Cretaceous-Cenozoic exhumation of the Yanji area,  NE China: insights from low-temperature thermochronology
literatureList.referenceEn: Li, X.M. (2019). Study on late Cretaceous-Cenozoic exhumation of the Yanji area,NE China: insights from low-temperature thermochronology. Acta Geochimica, 38(06), 43-61.

background: Northeastern (NE) China is geologically located in the eastern segment of the Central Asian Orogenic Belt (CAOB), intersected in the Siberian Craton, North China Block (NCB) and Western Pacific Plate. NE China was formed by the continental margin accretion and continent–continent collisions. Since the Paleozoic, it has undergone the evolution of the Paleo-Asian Ocean, the Mongol-Okhotsk Sea and the circum-Pacific tectonic domain. The subduction of the Paleo-Asian Ocean from the early Paleozoic to the early Mesozoic forms the CAOB, then the Mongol-Okhotsk Ocean closed diachronously in a scissor-like fashion from west to east during the Middle Jurassic and the Early Cretaceous, signifying the completion of the accretion of the East Asian Continent, and finally, the NE China and the adjacent region has become part of the circum-Pacific tectonomagmatic belt since the Late Mesozoic. The Yanji area, located at the border of China, Russia, and Korea and about 100 km west of the Japan Sea, was considered as a part of the orogenic collage between NCB in the south and the Jiamusi-Khanka Massifs in the northeast. Consequently, the Yanji area is the most likely location where subduction-related magmatic activities and subsequent exhumation processes would occur. The Phanerozoic granitoids have been extensively exposed in the Yanji area, suggesting that the rocks overlying these granitoids have largely been removed. The total exhumation since the Late Cretaceous was on the kilometer scale.
research objective: We report, in this study, new low-temperature thermochronology of apatite and zircon data from the granitoid samples in the Yanji area, including 16 AFT ages and 7 track length data, 16 ZFT ages, 8 AHe ages and 3 ZHe ages, and integrate with 6 AFT ages, 6 track length data and 6 ZFT ages from Li et al. (2010). These data can help us to obtain a clearer insight into the late-stage cooling and inferred exhumation history of granitoids in the Yanji area, NE China, and to place this within the context of the regional tectonic history of the western margin of the Pacific plate. To better interpret the significance of our data, we modeled the data by HeFTy software to quantify the timing and amount of cooling at specific sites with eight apatite FT data, in combination with AHe data sets as far as possible.
methods: Twenty-two representative samples, in this study, were collected for FT and (U–Th–Sm)/He analyses from the Phanerozoic granitoids in the Yanji area. Especially eight samples were collected from the Tianfozhishan at * 100–200 m elevation intervals. The prepared samples were carefully ground and polished to an optical finish to expose internal grain surfaces. Then, apatite spontaneous fission tracks were revealed by 5.5 M HNO3 at 21 °C for 20 s, and zircon by a molten 8 g NaOH ? 11.5 g KOH eutectic at 220 °C for 20–60 h, as necessary to obtain a high-quality etch. AHe and ZHe thermochronology was performed at the University of Melbourne, Australia. Euhedral zircon and apatite crystals without fracture or U/Th-rich inclusion were handpicked for analysis. Grains with a diameter greater than 70 lm were preferred where possible in order to ensure helium gas values were optimal for measurement and to minimize the alpha ejection correction.
dataset: Twenty-two representative samples, in this study, were collected for FT and (U–Th–Sm)/He analyses from the Phanerozoic granitoids in the Yanji area. We report, in this study, new low-temperature thermochronology of apatite and zircon data from the granitoid samples in the Yanji area, including 16 AFT ages and 7 track length data, 16 ZFT ages, 8 AHe ages and 3 ZHe ages, and integrate with 6 AFT ages, 6 track length data and 6 ZFT ages from Li et al. (2010).
findings: The results show that the maximum exhumation is likely [ 3.0 km since the Late Cretaceous, and the current elevation is commonly a few 100 m in the Yanji area, which has been characterized by continental deposits since the Early Mesozoic, thus suggesting the occurrence of negligible surface uplift and total unroofing of at least [ 2 km since the Late Cretaceous. This study revealed the more details about the cooling and inferred exhumation, for example, differential uplift and denudation between the Oligocene-Early Miocene and the Middle Miocene, and proposed higher paleogeothermal gradient ([ 35 °C/km), reflecting exhumation of [ 3 km, probably less than of [ 5 km from Li et al. (2010).

Verification.Question: Can the (U–Th–Sm)/He thermochronology method be effectively used to analyze apatite and zircon samples from Phanerozoic granitoids?
Do the apatite and zircon data from the Yanji area provide insight into the late-stage cooling and inferred exhumation history of granitoids?
Is the external detector method used to obtain apatite fission track ages in the data collection process?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the data collection methods used for obtaining low-temperature thermochronology data from granitoid samples in the Yanji area?
Where are the representative samples for the thermochronological data collected in the context of the Yanji area's geological studies?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to determine (U-Th-[Sm])/He ages for apatite and zircon in low-temperature thermochronology?
Example.Answer: A data collection method involves using an 820nm light-coupled semiconductor laser for degassing apatite and zircon, followed by analysis with inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry to determine (U-Th-[Sm])/He ages.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that includes thermochronological data from Phanerozoic granitoids in a specific region?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset includes low-temperature thermochronology data from the Yanji area, NE China, consisting of 16 AFT ages and 7 track length data, 16 ZFT ages, 8 AHe ages, and 3 ZHe ages, along with integrated data from previous studies.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the defining characteristics of low-temperature thermochronology datasets related to granitoid samples?
Feature Specification.Answer: fission track ages, track length data, (U-Th-[Sm])/He ages, external detector methods, helium analysis through laser de-gassing, mass spectrometry

Quantification.Question: How many samples were collected for the FT and (U–Th–Sm)/He analyses in a dataset from the Phanerozoic granitoids in the Yanji area?
What is the total number of low-temperature thermochronology data points obtained from apatite and zircon in a dataset from the Yanji area?
Quantification.Answer: 16 AFT ages, 7 track length data, 16 ZFT ages, 8 AHe ages, 3 ZHe ages, 6 AFT ages, 6 track length data, 6 ZFT ages

Quantification.Question: How many samples were specifically collected from the Tianfozhishan region at various elevation intervals for a dataset?

Definition.Question: What does 'low-temperature thermochronology' mean in the context of geological studies?
Definition.Answer: Low-temperature thermochronology refers to the study of the thermal history of rocks, specifically the temperature changes they have undergone over time. In geological studies, it involves analyzing mineral samples, such as apatite and zircon, to determine the timing and rate of cooling, which can provide insights into the exhumation and tectonic history of a region.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for apatite fission track analysis compare to those for (U-Th-[Sm])/He thermochronology in terms of sample preparation and analytical procedures?
Comparison.Answer: Apatite fission track analysis involves revealing spontaneous fission tracks by etching with 5.5 M HNO3 at 21°C for 20 seconds, whereas (U-Th-[Sm])/He thermochronology requires careful handpicking of euhedral crystals without fractures or U/Th-rich inclusions, with a preference for grains greater than 70 micrometers in diameter to ensure optimal helium gas measurement.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in dataset composition between apatite fission track ages and zircon fission track ages collected from the Yanji area's granitoid samples?
Comparison.Answer: The dataset for apatite fission track ages includes 16 AFT ages and 7 track length data, while zircon fission track ages comprise 16 ZFT ages. Additionally, the dataset integrates 6 AFT ages and 6 track length data along with 6 ZFT ages from previous research.

Comparison.Question: In terms of inferred exhumation history, how do the findings from apatite thermochronology compare to those from zircon thermochronology in the Yanji area?
Comparison.Answer: Findings from apatite thermochronology indicate a high paleogeothermal gradient and exhumation of more than 3 km, while zircon thermochronology supports these observations by revealing differential uplift and denudation patterns between the Oligocene-Early Miocene and the Middle Miocene, suggesting similar exhumation magnitudes.

Interpretation.Question: What interpretations can be drawn about the geological history of NE China from the integration of low-temperature thermochronology data of apatite and zircon in granitoid samples?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of low-temperature thermochronology data of apatite and zircon in granitoid samples from NE China can shed light on the late-stage cooling and exhumation history of the region. These interpretations help place the geological history within the context of the regional tectonic evolution, particularly concerning the western margin of the Pacific plate.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways might the data patterns from FT and (U–Th–Sm)/He analyses contribute to understanding the absence of significant surface uplift in the Yanji area since the Late Cretaceous?
Interpretation.Answer: The data patterns from FT and (U–Th–Sm)/He analyses suggest minimal surface uplift and a total unroofing of at least 2 km since the Late Cretaceous. These findings indicate that the region's elevation changes are primarily due to exhumation rather than surface uplift, providing insights into the geological processes that shaped the Yanji area.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors influence the choice of low-temperature thermochronology methods, such as apatite and zircon data, in understanding the cooling and exhumation history of granitoids?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The choice of low-temperature thermochronology methods like apatite and zircon data in understanding the cooling and exhumation history is influenced by the need to obtain accurate ages and track length data from samples, which can provide insights into the late-stage cooling and inferred exhumation history. The geological context of the region and the characteristics of the granitoids, such as their exposure and history of magmatic activities, also play a critical role.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of integrating multiple datasets from different studies on the overall understanding of a region's exhumation and cooling history?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating multiple datasets from different studies, such as combining new thermochronology data with existing data, can provide a more detailed and nuanced understanding of a region's exhumation and cooling history. This approach allows for cross-validation and can reveal trends and patterns that might not be apparent in a single dataset, leading to a more robust interpretation of geological processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting low-temperature thermochronology data from apatite and zircon in the Yanji area?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main goal is to obtain insights into the late-stage cooling and inferred exhumation history of granitoids in the Yanji area, NE China, and to understand this within the context of the regional tectonic history of the western margin of the Pacific plate.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the steps involved in preparing samples for fission track and (U–Th–Sm)/He analyses in granitoid studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The prepared samples are carefully ground and polished to an optical finish to expose internal grain surfaces. Apatite spontaneous fission tracks are revealed by etching with 5.5 M HNO3 at 21 °C for 20 seconds, and zircon by a molten 8 g NaOH ? 11.5 g KOH eutectic at 220 °C for 20–60 hours, as necessary to obtain a high-quality etch.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the helium gas measurement optimized in (U–Th–Sm)/He thermochronology analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Euhedral zircon and apatite crystals without fracture or U/Th-rich inclusion are handpicked for analysis. Grains with a diameter greater than 70 micrometers are preferred where possible to ensure helium gas values are optimal for measurement and to minimize the alpha ejection correction.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are followed to integrate AFT, ZFT, AHe, and ZHe data for thermochronological modeling in geological studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data is modeled using HeFTy software to quantify the timing and amount of cooling at specific sites. This involves integrating eight apatite FT data with AHe data sets, as far as possible, to interpret the significance of the data in terms of the cooling and inferred exhumation history.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the acquisition of low-temperature thermochronology data from granitoid samples in geological studies?
Enablement.Answer: The collection of low-temperature thermochronology data from granitoid samples is enabled by fission track (FT) and (U–Th–Sm)/He analyses. Representative samples are collected from the field, carefully ground, and polished to expose internal grain surfaces. Apatite and zircon crystals are etched to reveal spontaneous fission tracks and analyzed using methods like AHe and ZHe thermochronology, which are performed at specialized facilities like the University of Melbourne.

Enablement.Question: How do technological advancements in etching techniques contribute to the accurate measurement of apatite and zircon fission tracks in geological samples?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements in etching techniques, such as using 5.5 M HNO3 for apatite and a molten NaOH-KOH eutectic for zircon, allow for the precise revelation of spontaneous fission tracks. These methods ensure high-quality etching necessary for accurate measurements, contributing to the reliability of geological studies focusing on thermochronology and exhumation history.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do sample selection criteria enhance the quality and reliability of thermochronology data in geological research?
Enablement.Answer: Sample selection criteria enhance data quality by prioritizing euhedral zircon and apatite crystals without fractures or U/Th-rich inclusions. Grains with diameters greater than 70 micrometers are preferred to optimize helium gas measurements and minimize alpha ejection corrections. This meticulous selection process ensures the reliability and accuracy of the thermochronology data obtained.

Expectation.Question: Why might the expected exhumation levels differ from the observed levels in similar geological settings?
Expectation.Answer: The results show significant exhumation and negligible surface uplift in the Yanji area, suggesting that differential uplift and denudation patterns, as well as variations in paleogeothermal gradients, could result in differing exhumation levels in similar geological settings.

Expectation.Question: What are the potential reasons for discrepancies in expected versus observed cooling rates when analyzing granitoid samples?
Expectation.Answer: The study utilized low-temperature thermochronology to model the cooling and exhumation history of granitoids, which may vary due to factors such as differential uplift, denudation rates, or changes in geothermal gradients over time.

Expectation.Question: Why might anticipated data from similar granitoid formations not align with the data collected from the Yanji area?
Expectation.Answer: The Yanji area's unique geological history, including its position within the orogenic collage and its specific tectonic activities, could lead to distinct data outcomes that may not align with those from other granitoid formations.

Judgmental.Question: What is your assessment of the current datasets' ability to model cooling and exhumation histories effectively, and how might future datasets be improved in this field?
Judgmental.Answer: Current datasets, comprising AFT, ZFT, AHe, and ZHe ages, effectively model cooling and exhumation histories, providing valuable insights into regional tectonic activities. However, future datasets could be improved by expanding sample coverage and integrating additional thermochronological techniques to enhance spatial and temporal resolution, thereby providing a more comprehensive understanding of geological processes.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how data from thermochronological techniques can accurately reflect the cooling and exhumation history of geological samples.
Assertion.Answer: The dataset includes low-temperature thermochronology of apatite and zircon data, which helps in obtaining insights into the late-stage cooling and inferred exhumation history. Techniques like fission track analysis and (U–Th–Sm)/He dating are used to study the cooling history of rocks which can be correlated with exhumation processes.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how representative samples are selected for thermochronology studies in the context of geological research.
Assertion.Answer: In the context of the dataset, twenty-two representative samples were collected from Phanerozoic granitoids in the Yanji area. Special consideration was given to collecting samples from specific elevation intervals and ensuring that the samples were representative of the geological features under study.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate potential datasets that could complement the existing thermochronology data from the Yanji area and enhance the understanding of the region's tectonic history.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets could include additional geochemical data, seismic profiles, and paleomagnetic records from the Yanji area. These datasets could provide complementary insights into the tectonic processes and help validate the cooling and exhumation history inferred from thermochronology data.
